An attempt to make lithopanes using PLA.  Negative versions of the Sun, Moon plaques, thing:792943, are given; that is the layers of plastic are inverted, thin where the original was thick, and thick where the original was thin. Parameters were introduced into openSCAD polyhedron commands to make lithopane experiments easy.  More information is given in the openSCAD code.

To make these lithopanes work we need PLA which passes a fair amount of light when 0.4 mm thick and blocks most light when 4 or 5 mm thick.  Translucent PLA's pass too much light and most colored PLA's block too much light.   Makerbot's "true white" PLA was used although a PLA which passes a bit more light would be preferable.  The plaques were printed standing on edge with 0.2 mm layers and 100% infill.  The image above shows the plaques hanging in a window.

comments.text: Thanks for the comments and information.  My ABS printer is down due to a blown power regulator and I can only print PLA.  Natural ABS is a better choice for lithopanes. This hot tub float is printed in 3 pieces.  The main float is a hollow, floating container that holds 2" chlorine or bromine pucks.  It has a rotating ring that adjusts the amount of chemical dispensed.  And, it has a lid that snaps on the top.  The hollow float is something that can only be manufactured by 3D printing !  It's not possible to injection mold such a product with a hollow interior.

Print the 3 pieces and then just snap the ring around the bottom of the float.  The lettering on the front is the name of my enterprise, i3DGear, and I just filled it with tiling grout to make the letter's stand out.  Just using grout to fill in lettering is a great solution, much easier than mucking about with dual extrusion printing.  
When the main float is printing, depending on your slicing engine, you may notice that it's filling the float with a honeycomb of material.  This is fine and contributes to its un-sinkable-ness - ie. multiple chambers.  You can turn down the 'infill' setting on your 3D printing slicing engine to 2 or 3% when you print it and it will make the honeycombing more sparse and use less plastic.

comments.text: I've had the float in my hot tub for 2 months now, no degradation.  Actually, the picture posted is of the float after the two months.  ABS plastic melts at 230F, your hot tub is only at about 100F, so no problem.  And, ABS plastic is the same plastic that is used for drain pipes in houses and in pools, where chlorine is present.  So, it is quite safe from degradation from chlorine or the building codes departments wouldn't spec it for use in pools and drains.  I don't know if I'd use PLA as it is biodegradable and probably wouldn't stand up to the environment in a hot tub.

title: Nikon Prostaff 3-9 X 40 Scope Thumb Adjustable Knob to set elevation / windage

description.text:
I have a 5 year old Nikon Prostaff 3-9 X 40 rifle scope without the thumb-adjustable turret knobs..... This is not fire-tested, but works well on the bench. Probably will be better than using a nickle to adjust windage / elevation, as you wont have to move your eye from the scope. Feb. 19, 2016 These knobs worked great; Last week I finally got my .223 hitting steel from 100 yards. I adjusted by using the "dust clouds" of impacts on the dirt hill behind the 12" steel pig target until I got it on steel. Now I need to fine tune with paper targets. Having the knobs made this quick and easy - about 5 minutes and 20 rounds. May 2016 UPDATE: Spring Diameter: 13.26 mm / 0.522" (+/-)
Spring Free Length: 19.24 mm / 0.757" (+/-)
Spring Wire Diameter: 0.82 mm / 0.0325" (+/-) I just used this one set of knobs to sight in a Kel-Tec SU-16 5.56 and an AR-15 5.56. These knobs made it so easy to get on bulls eye quickly. Note: I made this to fit some springs I already had. Next time I take them off, I will measure them so that you can locate the correct spring...... Or possibly redesign this for readily available springs. THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS.

title: Z Probe Mount for  i3 Rework Extruder

description.text:
A simple Z probe mount for 12mm inductive sensors for any Prusa i3 Rework extruder with mounting holes in the base. I created this one for my CharlStruder ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:678089 ) which has two additional mounting holes. If your extruder base does not have mounting holes you can always drill them. Just remember to make sure the mount is fairly level. You can also use the existing hole by using longer screws to mount both the extruder and the probe mount. It is designed to work with hole spacings up to 32mm.
The no support version is printable without support but has more limited hole spacing support. Depending on the location on your X=0, Y=0 you will need to mount you probe either to the left of to the right so that the sensor is over the bed when you hot end is in the home position. Please select the appropriate model.

comments.text: Many inductive sensors including mine (which it sounds like you are using) register as triggered when away from the bed and only show not triggered when the are close to the bed. Take a metal object like a screwdriver and put it close to the tip of the sensor. Does the LED come on? Does it show as not triggered now? You can set in the firmware if the you sensor if ON when close to the bed or OFF.

author: psibob3

title: PLAyPin a 3D Printed Medium Format Pinhole Camera

description.text: While there are already a few fantastic designs out there like the TerraPin and the P6x6 I wanted to design my own. My main reason was that the other cameras had very long print times, I wanted to go with a more modular design so I could print an hour or two here and there. The longest printing time with the PLAyPin is the body and on my printer with 0.4mm layer height and 15% honeycomb infill takes 3.5hrs, the rest are all under an hour each. I also tried to be as efficient as possible to keep the amount of filament down. While this camera is designed for medium format film you can easily shoot 35mm too using Coconnor55's brilliant adapter http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:323120 the photos in the gallery were taken using these adapters. Hopefully you enjoy my design!

DO NOT PRINT THE ALL IN ONE STL, that is just for show, download the zip file with the individual parts.  
All parts are designed for printing on a 0.4mm nozzle. I usually print with 0.4mm layer height with 2 perimeters, 2 top/bottom layers, and 15% honeycomb infill.  
For assembly instructions please see the pdf file included.

author: AwesomeA

description.text:
The LIDAR unit salvaged from a Neato XV11 Robotic Vacuum Cleaner is a cheap LIDAR for robotics that reports accurate range information up to 3-5M in a continuous 360 Degree scan.  
This is a stand to suit the XV11 Lidar and has primarily been designed for working on the desk while testing or demonstrating, but could be attached to a base of a robot as is.
The controller and firmware is a remix of a similar Teensyduino Controller by Get Surreal (http://www.getsurreal.com/product/xv-lidar-controller-v1-2)

Designed to suit Sparkfun 5V Pro Micro board. (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12640) Motor control is via a dual H-Bridge L9110 that sits on the centre standoff, where I'm only using 1 channel. (http://www.dx.com/p/l9110-dual-channel-h-bridge-motor-driver-module-for-arduino-black-157149#.VT8B38622NU) I may look at incorporating one of dx.com MOSFET boards as I only had the L9110 on hand and is a bit of overkill for the application, however it works as its currently designed. The Lid is snug push fit and I've included a 3mm LED hole for the status LED.

• Firmware: https://github.com/madeinoz67/XV_Lidar_Controller
  • Visual Test Software: http://www.getsurreal.com/products/xv-lidar-controller/xv-lidar-controller-visual-test

2015/07/29 Added Geomagic Design Package, i.e. CAD Source files  
2015/04/30 Schematics PDF now available in Thing Files   
2015/04/28 V4.0 Lid now with 3mm LED, increased height of pro micro enclosure, fixed slight misalignment on main standoffs.  
2015/04/28 V2.0 Lid fixes

Tall standoffs require cooling fan on and can be turned on at approx. layer 15  
Lid will need to be flipped 180Deg for printing.   
LED Hole will more than likely need a drill run through it.

1x X11 LIDAR unit from ebay
1x 3mm LED and resister
1x Sparkfun Pro Micro - https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12640
1x dx.com L9110 H-Bridge (but any MOSFET driver board will do) - http://www.dx.com/p/l9110-dual-channel-h-bridge-motor-driver-module-for-arduino-black-157149#.VT8B38622NU
See Thing Files for Schematic

title: XL Heated Glass Build Platform PCB 300mm x 150mm

description.text:
Small Update:
I added a picture of the 8 rows of ditto capabilities (I was still testing the hairspray method, so one part came off)
I don't think the LED on top is a good idea any more. It flickers too much and has become annoying. This is a replacement build platform for your Makerbot Replicator (single or dual). It takes advantage of the extra space along the x axis that is not currently used.
If you have taken advantage of the Sailfish firmware upgrade, you can use the ditto functionality to get two more columns of parts on one build plate. If you just want to use single extrusion, this will let you build 33mm wider with either the right, or left extruder.
The extra surface area of the build plate will take longer to heat up, so you should only do this modification if you want the extra room, or if most of your prints are multi-hour affairs. Here is the saga that led up to my larger HBP:
My original aluminum HBP was slightly warped from the start. I haven't been too bothered by it until I started printing with PLA.
The plate is slightly dished when cool, and domed when hot. I can't print on the corners with ABS, but I can't print at all when the plate is cool. I decided to switch to a glass build plate. I got two borosilicate
plates 12x6x1/4 from McMaster Carr. (I should have probably gotten the 3/16, but I couldn't resist the 1/4" for the same price.) I found that the heat wouldn't even think about creeping out to the "wings" through the glass. It only conducts the heat straight up.
I took some thermal images from the original plate, and the smaller glass. See the PDFs for comments on my findings. I decided to use information from Gary's update http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43207 and some of my own electrical experience to make my own plate.
It has 2 zones of trace with the outer zone packed more closely together and the inner zone spaced apart. There are no screw holes, because the screws are attached to trace left on the bottom. Here are the specs for each zone: Both zones are .75 mm wide on 1oz, copper double sided PCB paralleled together so each receives 24VDC.
Center zone is 259 cm area, 11,484mm long trace, 7.44 Ohms, drawing 3.23 Amps for a total wattage of 77.62. Watts per sq.cm is 0.30.
Outside zone is 200 cm area, 13,268mm long trace, 8.59 Ohms, drawing 2.79 Amps for a total wattage of 66.87. Watts per sq.cm is 0.33 - 10% more than the center. I cut the new design on the engraver at work after hours. I was shooting for a parallel resistance of 4 Ohms so I would draw a similar 6 Amps as the original. Hit it on
the first try! The new plate takes longer to reach temperature because it has more surface area, and the thick glass I got. The original and the 3/16 glass on the original
HBP board took about 8 minutes. The new one took 16 minutes or so. It is in my unheated garage, and I had my sides off, so it probably won't take that long with it all
buttoned up. The glass holds the heat between prints more than the aluminum plate did. I plan on swapping out the plates when I am making lots of parts. I will find a way
to store the spare plate near the top of the hood, so it is warmed up for the next go. Let me know what you think, or if you have any questions. I haven't made files for PCBs before, so if you need something else, let me know in the comments.

When I took my old board off, I noticed the LED wasn't working. The original connector from MBI was wired reversed polarity for the heat. The LED is dead!
The new High brightness LED is on the top surface of the tab, pointing into the edge of the glass. It lights the glass beautifully, and I can write on the bottom surface
for glowing lettering or logos while building! Here is the place I got information on resistance of copper PCB: http://circuitcalculator.com/wordpress/2006/01/24/trace-resistance-calculator/
I am working on a system to clip the glass down. I left all the copper on the bottom, so I could solder on parts around the edge. The new platform is 37mm wider on both sides than the original. So far, I have printed ditto with a sliced model for the right extruder with these settings: Far left column of objects placed at the far left of the normal area. Far right column of objects placed 33mm over the edge of the normal area. Turn on ditto printing, and get 2 more columns worth of objects on the new platform. I have also sliced and printed single extruder models that are up to 33mm longer than possible before. You need to be careful to set them up in the right spot: Models printed with the right extruder hang off on the right side, left extruder models hang off on the left. Making the board: Use the top and bottom PDF marked "trace" to etch the 1oz. board (the black lines are where copper should remain), or use the PDF marked "cut" to mill a .75mm wide gap between the remaining copper traces (the lines are center of the tool path). Test the resistance of the trace. It should be about 4 Ohms. Put the components onto the board, and wire it up with a remote connection, or solder the existing wires directly onto the board to prevent connector failure. Components: 4.7K resistor goes between the signal and 5V (white and blue on mine) 1.0K resistor series with a high brightness white LED between the +24V and Heat - (I made mine wrap around the tab and point into the edge of the glass platform to light it up!) 0.1Uf capacitor between the gnd and sig near the tab 100K surface mount thermistor at the center of the plate between gnd and sig.

A few years ago in college a professor had a pretty cool desk toy that has apparently been discontinued. It looks kind of funky but the center of gravity stays at about the same level as it rolls. I decided you should be able to do a 3d print of it! Model: http://engy.us/misc/wobbler.stl

inspired by Mayan culture

Do you wonder why your clothes are always wrinkled?  Tired of spending countless hour ironing your shirts and slacks and/or skirts and blouses? Do you feel like your life is a frustrating black and white segment on an infomercial? If only you had a way to hang up those clothes instead of having piles of clothes on the floor.  Now you can build a cheap or mostly free ersatz closet with this handy dandy 4-way connector and simple pieces of round wood (from trees!).  Stop being in the black and white segment and throwing your wrinkly clothes down with a frustrated scowl on your face and join me in the color segment, where we smile all the time!  Build a better place to hang up your clothes, you slob!  
Connects four (4) 2.5" dowels.  Connect all the dowels and make a cheap or mostly free place to hang up your clothes.  Now with a little hole to put a screw through! Hangers not included.  Dowels not included.

Rotate so that the 3 connectors are on the bed.  If you do, there's no need for support.  If you don't you'll probably need lots of support, so just rotate that model.  
Print @ .2 mm per layer.  I printed @ 50% infill, to make sure it's extra beefy, so the clothes don't end up in a pile on the floor again.  
Print on a raft to make sure that first layer adheres so dimensions are correct.  
Deftly modeled in 123d Design.

author: Xaalman

description.text: This is a customizable approximately n-scale building generator intended for creating building terrain for use in Dropzone Commander.

There are two approaches in these files:  
The individual OpenSCAD files, and the STLs I've uploaded that were generated with them, allow you to produce each face of each floor individually then assemble a whole building from them. This allows you to make an arbitrarily large building no matter the size of your printbed.  
The whole_assembly.zip file, and the OpenSCAD files it contains, allows you to create a solid building in a single STL. I've uploaded two STLs produced with these files, one smooth and one with the brick texture, which are identical in configuration to the pictured example building. This is generally simpler to print, but ultimately limits you to producing a building no larger than your printable area.  
In both approaches, the OpenSCAD files have a few different configuration settings at the top in three blocks:
Here you can select the number of wall units you want generated at one time, whether you want the wall, the corner, or both, and whether or not you want a door (ground floor only).
These settings allow you to change the number of windows, whether or not to even have windows, if the brick effect will be applied to the surface, and if you want the stand pipe included.

These settings let you tweak the nitty gritty details. You can change the distances between windows, between the bottom and top of the windows and the bottom and top of the wall, the overall height of the wall, and so on.

You'll need to print these upright, because otherwise the brick and window detail will all get lost in the nozzle resolution. I've successfully printed all these files multiple times on a .5mm nozzle, so you can do it with standard equipment.  
If you have a resin printer, you will of course get a much nicer output, and the fine features that you see in the renders will come out much better. If you do print this on a resin printer, please upload photos! I'd love to see it.

description.text:
Currently my son is really into Octonauts, a kids show he found on Netflix.  Of course he wants all the toys now too.  
I was looking a some of the pictures on a website of the toys, and I realized that the shape of this particular craft was pretty basic, and the core of the model was just an elongated sphere.  
So I took a stab at it in Tinkercad, and I was able to come up with something pretty close.  I tried printing a couple different ways, but in the end I had to cut it in half and glue it together.  I modeled some small holes in each half to use as alignment pins.  I just used some snips of 1.75 filament for the pins.  I did have to drill them out a little but it all worked fine.  
For #MakeItFloat I can confirm that making the bottom half in .75 infill, and the top half .25 infill helps keep the Gup upright and floating.  When tipped, the bottom heavy part goes does and keeps it from floating upside down.  
He's over the moon about this toy, and now wants me to model all the other Gup craft.  :)

Print each half.  I printed the bottom half with .75 infill and the top half with .25 infill on the theory that it will stay upright in the tub.  Confirmed that this works well for #MakeItFloat and keeps it upright.  
After printing, I had to redrill the alignment holes I had put in the model, since they didn't come out to 2mm.  But it was easy to drill.  
I used some snips of 1.75mm filament to line up each half, and just hot glued the model together.  
Insert Octonaut toy (preferably Kwazi) and away you go!  Yar! Shiver me whiskers!  Etc. Etc.

title: Adjustable Wheelchair for a handicapped puppy dog

description.text:
As we adopted the handicapped puppy Luisa which was born without front legs, our engineers at Multec designed this wheelchair for her. Here is a german tv-documentation about our lovely Luisa:
http://swrmediathek.de/player.htm?show=0fcb0d80-3148-11e5-875e-0026b975f2e6
There are two versions available: one for grown dogs and a second for puppys. Luisa is 6 months and still growing and will be about 50-60cm when grown up.
The wheelchair is designed to fit all sizes of dogs because of its adjustable tube frame. It is also designed in order to install more stabilizing wheels for the training in the front and beneath.
Later on, it will be used with only two wheels, but therefore Luisa has to learn to balance. In addition she needs to train her back and back feet, but as you can see in the video, she is on a good way.
At the moment she uses the puppy wheelchair:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ModnXZLg7_s More about Luisa: https://www.facebook.com/luisas.tagebuch and http://www.luisas-blog.de

The instructions can be downloaded here:
https://www.multec.de/Hunderollstuhl-aus-dem-3D-Drucker (german)
https://www.multec.de/Wheelchair-from-a-3D-Printer (english) As Luisa is growing, we will update all of our experiences there as well. Such as addtional training wheels and other improvements. This will be a work in progress together with Luisa, our lovely little dog.

title: RCTimer Trooper Y6 alternative motor mounts

description.text: This is an alternative motor mount for the RCTimer Trooper Y6 multicopter, designed by user frj79 in the Trooper thread on rcgroups.com. I helped with the printing and thought others might be interested in the STL file as well.

Print in ABS or PETG, do not print in PLA (it will not hold). Use a brim to make sure the mount comes out flat.  
You will need 4 mounts per arm, in total 12 mounts for all motors. Use carbon fiber plates on top of the mounts to attach the motors, as shown in the images.  
I used 25% infill and it is plenty strong but only weighs about 3 grams per mount. You can add more infill if you want to make it even stronger.

title: Parametric Card Tray for Board Games

description.text:
Card tray for board game card stacks. Essential for keeping tall piles of sleeved cards from falling over during play.  
I have printed tons of these in different sizes for a lot of different games. Se Instructions for tips on how to customize this for different sized cards and stack heights. The default values are for my standard tray for Card Driven GMT games with draw and discard pile, for cards sleeved with Arcane Tinmen Standard sized Board Game Sleeves (grey), as is depicted in the picture with Wilderness War.  
The design is parametric regarding card dimensions, stack height, material thickness, and the number of tray rows and columns.

I normally make a stack of 10 or 20 cards and measure that with a vernier caliper. Then, for my printer, an added 3 mm in both width and height gives a good, just right, fit. Depth is customized depending on the need of each particular game depending on expected stack height. 2 mm wall thickness is usually plenty. Following is a short list of the dimensions in millimeters of a few different sleeve sizes that I commonly use. (Don't forget to add a few millimeters, I do 3, not to get a too tight fit.) Best is of course to measure for yourself, but it's added in case it's helpful to someone.
  • Arcane Tinmen Small (red) 46 x 72
  • Arcane Tinmen Standard (grey) 67 x 94
  • Arcane Tinmen Medium (green) 59 x 93
  • Arcane Tinmen Large (blue) 63 x 97
  • FFG Square (for Power Grid) 73 x 73
  • FFG Yellow (Eldritch horror) 44 x 67.3
  • Mayday War of the Ring 71 x 122

title: Customizable fancy pencil holder (you choose the number)

description.text: I was asked to make a 'nice' pencil holder. I provide the openscad file so you can set how many pencils you want it to hold. The customizer now allows you to change the slope  of the pencils and you can preview the stand with the pencils in it as well.

The stl is for a 48 pencil holder (it's almost 200 mm in diameter). If you change the 'number_pencils' variable in openscad then you can set the number of pencils to hold and the diameter of the holder adjusts accordingly.
You can preview the stand with the pencils in it as well. Make sure the pencils don't try to occupy the same space!

comments.text: Hi! I've done many reviews in the past, such as the book willow in google reviews, and I just had to say that, though this may look cool on the surface there was actually many different things going on. Now you may think,"what other things?" Well I shall tell you. At first glance and the base portion of this website, it would seem that this project was made by a 3D printer, now no one blames you for thinking this but you're wrong. This was actually made by 23 young children, it was not slave labor, but I would still appreciate it if you gave them credit. Thx >-< #ObamaOut

author: Romano76

description.text:
So I had some spare cheap servos and arduino lying around and decided to build a cheap hexapod. Pieces are meant to be easy to print and fit precisely to TowerPro SG90 or SG92 micro servos. Desing was inspired and partly copied from funghy's hexapod https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56698
Idea and code to precisely control 18 servos with arduino was taken from http://www.lamja.com/?p=504
I also modified Arvid's code to work on arduino leonardo with Atmega32u4 chip. You can get 20 servos for 30$ from aliexpress. Arduino nano is 4$, step-down converter for a battery is few bucks, ESP8266 wifi module for arduino is few more bucks so total bill is less than 50$ excluding battery. Edit: added top and bottom plates. Those are pretty much scaled versions of funghy's hexapod but I'll make another ones to precisely fit battery, arduino and other stuff.

comments.text: Hi I liked the form of this hexapod and used it in some videos http://gigabrain.io Our app uses Raspberry Pi and PCA9685 boards to control the hexapod. You can join the beta testing stage if you'd like to control your hexapod.

Thanks and Regards!

This device is probably not all that useable for anyone but me, but put it up here for inspiration.
I have this autonomous boat that is used for mapping the seafloor and as I recently bought a waterproof video camera and I thought it might be cool to have it mounted on the boat. The bracket is tilt able so I can have the camera mounted at any angle for straight ahead to straight down.
Here is a link to my project http://letsmakerobots.com/node/21098

All the holes are under sized for either drill up to correct size or as for the top bracket drill and tap M6 for M6 rod. The swivel bracket has an indentation  to accommodate  an M6 Hex bolt and the same goes for the camera screw.

title: Y-Axis Bracket for Solidoodle 2/3 - Lipped version

description.text: This is a derivative of Chuck Murrays "Y-Axis Bracket for Solidoodle 2" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36446) . I printed his originally but found they had a bit too much propensity to twist on my Solidoodle 3. The originals had a small 'lip' that hugged the case edges ensuring they stayed straight - so I imported Chuck's into Sketchup and added the lips. As a result, the 'overkill' versions are no longer ambidextrous. Included is STL files for dual copies of either version.

Printed at 50% hexagonal infill with 4 perimeters.  
You will need to readjust the y-axis belt tension when you install this bracket. I also replaced my M3x0.5 button head cap screw because the bracket is thicker than the stock piece - I used an M3 phillips head screw that I had available. The stock 8mm long cap screw will work but a 10mm cap screw will ensure full thread engagement.

description.text: Replacement key housing for a 2003 Honda Accord (UK)

I Printed with ABS on a TAZ 5 240C/110C. I used the button layout from @Cleven's "Honda Key Housing Replacement" but found the electronics from my key was thicker than his, and we don't have a panic button. The electronics is a slightly different shape in order to leave some space for the imobiliser chip. The imobiliser chip is very important! It is a glass tube under a white plastic slip in the original honda key remove it carefully, wrap in blutac and insert into the space left in the printed key. If the imobiliser chip is missing and you put the key in the ignition, the ignition will lock the key in and you wont be able to start the engine or remove the key. If this happens just hold the imobiliser chip near the ignition.  
Files Updated 14 May 2015

title: Pastel Containers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Behold these beautifully bold containers! Inspired by nature and designed to be 3D printed. They make for some rather splendid prints. The designs look amazing planted up with succulents (which is what we did with them), but also make striking serving dishes or simply decorative containers. There are three designs to enjoy:
  • Cactus Cup
  • Ripple Bowl
  • Armadillo Dish

Print at 0.20mm layer height with 2 perimeters and 10% infill. A pattern has been added to the base of each design to help prevent warping (as well as making them look super cool). There are also some 'lilypads' on the 'dish' for additional warp prevention, as this has a larger base. We have also made avaialble the .STL files as solid filled objects. This to allow for faster prints in 'vase' mode (single shell with 0% infill) should you so wish. The prints shown have been done in Faberdashery Bubblegum Blue, Cherry Blossom Pink, Peppermint Cream, Sugarplum, Vanilla Milk and Pistachio Pie. We hope you enjoy them!

Translation at the bottom of the page Système permettant de protéger l’Arduino et de d'assurer la mise en place et l’enlèvement rapide d'une breadboard par un système à tiroir. Le support se compose principalement :
  • De quatre plots pour fixer l'Arduino Uno
  • De trous de fixations pour ajout d'une protection transparente sur le dessus de l'Arduino
  • D'un tiroir qui comporte des languettes de pression pour maintenir la plaque d'essai.
    La largeur de la platine d'essai doit être comprise entre 48 et 60 mm.
    Conçue pour une platine d’épaisseur nominale de 8,5 mm, effectuer un ajustement à la lime si besoin afin de limiter la deformation des languettes ressorts à 0,5 mm.
    Je protège le dessus de l'Arduino avec de la feuille plastique rigide récupérable sur des emballages de produits de consommations courantes.
    Laisser un espace entre la feuille plastique et le dessus de l'arduino au niveau du microcotroleur.
    • Une actualisation a été effectué, les plots sont moins hauts et avec un chanfrein plus important pour éviter un appui éventuel avec les soudures.

System to protect the Arduino and to ensure the installation and the quick removal of a breadboard by a system with drawer. The support consists mainly of: From four studs to fix the Arduino Uno Fixing holes for added transparent protection on the top of the Arduino A drawer having pressure tongues for holding the test plate. The width of the test plate shall be between 48 and 60 mm. Designed for a platinum with a nominal thickness of 8.5 mm, adjust the file if necessary to limit the deformation of the springs at 0.5 mm. I protect the top of the Arduino with rigid plastic sheet recoverable on packaging of products of current consumption. Leave a space between the plastic sheet and the top of the arduino at the microcotter. An update has been made, the studs are less high and with a larger chamfer to avoid possible support with the welds. Alain Ducroscreated this design

This printable extruder is intended to work on RepRap Mendel (both standard and Prusa), RepRap Huxley, and virtually any other open-source 3D printer you can find. It features:
  • 1.75 mm filament
  • Adaptable mounting plate to attach it to virtually any 3D printer
  • Very compact high-torque NEMA 11 motor
  • Active ducted fan cooling for high reliability
  • Wade-style hobbed bolt filament transport
  • Wing-nut drive to spread the torque loading on the plastic gears
  • Push-fit hot-end parts - no thread cutting
  • Easily replaced PTFE liner for the hot end
  • A single M3-threaded rod cut to lengths makes all the fixings
    1. Lightweight: 420g
    2. Compact design (110 mm x 90 mm x 80 mm)
    • I based this design (loosely) on Jstkatz's extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7037), in particular, the idea of using a lever to trap the filament against its drive.
The full Bill of Materials and detailed construction instructions are on the RepRap Wiki here: http://reprap.org/wiki/RepRap_Universal_Mini_Extruder.

comments.text: The air flows first over the pinch between the small bearing and the bolt.  All pinch extruders work a lot more reliably if the pinch point is kept as cold as possible.  Even slight warming will soften some plastics a bit, and then the drive starts to abrade the filament, rather than driving it.

title: Vintage Collection Hotel Casino Agua Caliente, Tijuana, México (1927)

description.text:
The Agua Caliente Casino and Resort opened in June 1928 in the Mexican city of Tijuana, Baja California. It was a lavish resort that included a casino, spa, championship golf and tennis facilities, its own airstrip, and lots of entertainment. Stylistically, the resort was an amalgam of Mexican colonial, California mission, and neo-Islamic designs that ranged from mosaic minarets, to cozy guest bungalows, to steaming Turkish baths.[1] It was designed by 19-year-old architect Wayne McAllister and built by Baron H. Long, Wirt G. Bowman and James N. Crofton. Some sources note the fourth partner was Abelardo L. Rodríguez, Military Commander and Governor of Baja California, and future Mexican President. [2] The $2.5 million Agua Caliente racetrack opened in December 1929.[3]  
Drinking, gambling and horse racing were illegal in the neighboring U.S. state of California, so many wealthy Americans and Hollywood celebrities flocked to Agua Caliente. The actress Rita Hayworth was discovered there while performing in a show. The films In Caliente and The Champ were filmed on location there. The highlight of the opulent casino was the Gold Room, where patrons could only bet using gold chips, with a rumored $500 minimum wager. Bugsy Siegel cited Agua Caliente as his inspiration for building the resort on what became the Las Vegas Strip.
